div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through steamers for Marseilles ad London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train deluxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £19.4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £ 1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 13-9-906

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1906.

div.head: THE SULTAN AND ENGLAND.
div.p: To-day is the anniversary of the accession of the Sultan, and in view of recent events it may well be asked whether it is possible to initiate a policy which may strengthen our position with Turkey. But as the "Morning Post" has pointed out, if we could reduce the problem to such simple component parts as Pan-Slavism versus Germany, Christianity versus Islam, added to the Porte versus Bulgaria, we might indeed see daylight ; but there is too great a proportion of x—the unknown quantity—to allow of any rough-and- ready solution. The basic fact is undoubtedly the general movement, the stirring of national and racial feeling in the Slav populations of the Balkans. This extraordinary upheaval of peoples, buried for four centuries under Ottoman rule, may partially be accounted for by the decadence of Turkish power in Europe, but there are other causes. The Czech revival in Bohemia is another manifestation of the same phenomenon, and there is no doubt that the extraordinary vitality of the Slavs has made them in the long run more than a match for their Turkish conquerors The rulers of Europe viewed this renascence with as much misgiving as the Porte, and in the Treaty of Berlin attempts were made to circumscribe it, to ensure that it should be confined within certain limits. Turkey became allied with Europe in the endeavour to keep the unruly Balkans within bounds, but the arrangement did not make sufficient allowance for the difficulties which were bound to arise when the religious question crossed the political one. The solidarity of Christianity against Islam is one of the fetiches of European polities, and it must be confessed that an unscrupulous use has been made of this weapon. Were the Christians in the Balkans as united as the tenets of their faith demand the issues might be narrowed within practicable limits, but the legacy of disunion between the Eastern and Western Churches was left in the Balkan States by the earliest missionaries from Rome and Byzantium ; and the various sects of the Catholic and Greek Orthodox Churches, even when akin, are so violently opposed as to assume different nationalities. The religious and political propaganda are so closely interwoven that it is impossible to disentangle them, and thus we get situations like that in Eastern Rumelia to-day, where Christians are engaged in murdering each other ruthlessly in a country under Moslem suzerainty. It is, in fact, impossible to postulate a case of Moslem versus Christian in the Balkans, and the desire of Christian peoples to assist their distressed co- religionists must be modified by the consideration that these Christians are in reality engaged in a warfare in which religion is not the casus belli.

The political situation is even more involved. Eastern Rumelia, where at present Christians are burning each other without mercy, was made, by the Treaty of Berlin, a province under the Sultan's direct military and political control, with a Christian Governor appointed by him and a local militia to ensure internal order. In 1885 a revolution occurred, and as a result, the province was united to Bulgaria and the Prince of that country be- came Governor-General. The people now desire to return to the article of the Berlin Treaty which secures Eastern Rumelia as an autonomous province under the direct rule of the Porte, and they press their countrymen of Bulgaria to make the necessary sacrifices to secure this position of Eastern Rumelia rather than allow the ambitions of the Pan-Hellenist to be realised. With regard to the latter it must be remembered that Greece had been little satisfied by the arrangements of the Treaty of Berlin, in which her claims received scant recognition. Lord Beaconsfield consoled her with the remark that "States, like individuals, which have a future are in a position to be able to wait." To illustrate, however, the feelings of the peoples of the Balkans towards those European Powers who desire to replace the rule of Turkey by their own,one may turn to Bosnia-Herzegovina, which since 1878 has been occupied and administered by Austria, though still nominally under Turkey. The people offered determined and prolonged resistance to this occupation, nor are they more than passively reconciled to the regime at present. They do not regard Austria as a saviour, rather as another alien conqueror. But if the feelings of the people are so mixed, so far from certain, in these two regions, where the political situation is more or less crystallised, what can be said of the state of affairs in Macedonia, where a dozen conflicting influences are at work ? To carry out the obligations which Europe incurred by the Berlin Treaty with regard to Christians in European Turkey, a programme of reform was initiated, and this region was placed under that sort of mixed control which generally leads to anarchy. Government by a syndicate, in which each member is playing to secure a special share of control, was, perhaps, not even a good exchange for the rule of the Turk. It cannot be claimed by the most optimistic that the intervention of the Powers has proved a success. It has not secured the Macedonian Christians nor improved the conditions of life for any of the population, and it has strengthened the hands of certain turbulent neighbouring Christian States, who have lost no opportunity of stirring up trouble for the Turks—still nominally responsible—to put down.

In the whole situation the factor which is most often neglected is that of Turkey, the suzerain Power. Is the "Sick Man of the East" really near his dissolution, and are we justified in discounting the partition of his European possessions ? Either Turkey in Europe must be bolstered up or we shall have Pan-Slavist union in Eastern Europe, a Pan-German combination in Central Europe, and incidentally, Great Britain nowhere. Put thus with crude brevity, it becomes apparent that the preservation of Turkey in Europe is actually favourable to our own position in the Near East, but it is not possible to subscribe to the inevitableness of the Austro-Hungarian "break up," nor is it easy to see the part to be played by Hungary in such a partition of Europe between Slav and Teuton. It is, moreover, becoming plain that there is too little real national or racial feeling in those Turkish provinces which are the chief seats of disturbance to allow for a real reconstruction of their States such as was accomplished in other parts of the Balkans. Their history is confused by a constant change of masters : one kingdom after another has overlapped, one wave of occupation after another has surged in and ebbed away, leaving a residuum. The population on the land does not share to any extent in the manœuvres of which it is the victim, nor is it, at present, conscious of race and nationality to the extent which its protagonists would have us believe. This being the case, and the difficulties of effecting an entire political reconstruction being so great, it may well be worth while for Great Britain to consider whether it would not be in the best interests of the countries most directly concerned (though not convenient to others) to return to Lord Beaconsfieid's declared policy of strengthening an ancient Empire—essential to the maintenance of peace,"

div.head: Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Alexandria via Port Said and Brindisi will close at 3.10 p. m. on Monday.

div.head: The French Carden.
div.p: The well known wild-beast tamers, the Maaserini, sill perform for the next few nights at the French Garden.

div.head: Al-Azhar University.
div.p: The summer vacation of Al-Azhar University euded yesterday and the theological students resumed their studies this morning.

div.head: The Hamamil Quarter.
div.p: The Alexandria City Police has opened a police station in the Hamamil quarter owing to the disorderly character of that part of the city.

div.head: Mad Camel.
div.p: A camel developed signs of madness a few days ago at Ezbet el Fawrakar, near Abou Kerkas, and bit a native woman so savagely that she succumbed shortly afterwards.

div.head: Dredging at Alexandria.
div.p: Of the balance of the credit opened at the end of last year for dredging the entrance to the port of Alexandria L. E. 15,878 have been expended, leaving a balance of L. E. 68,839.

div.head: Economy at Kasr El-Ali.
div.p: Hassan Pasha Assem, Director of the Kasr El-Ali Daira, has effected considerable economies in the expenses of that Daira and has reduced the salaries of its employés by L.E. 7,000.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: This evening at 9.30 o'clock Zola's "L'Asiommoir," will be given by the French Comedy Troupe. To-morrow, at 4.30 o'clock there will be a matinée performance of "Le Bonheur Conjugal" a vaudeville in three acts.

div.head: State Schools.
div.p: The entries thus far for this year to the various State Schools are as follows : 117 Khedivial Law School ; 83 School of Medicine; 31 Polytechnic School ; 23 Normal School; 100 Khedivieh School, 48 Tewfikieh School.

div.head: New Police School.
div.p: The lease of the Mohamad Pasha Cherif Palace, in the Rue Abdel Aziz, Cairo, which the Government have acquired for a police school, is for two years, at a rental of L.E. 1,000, to be increased to L.E. 1,500 should that period be extended.

div.head: Night Dispensary.
div.p: The "Société de Secours Medicale de Nuit" has opened a dispensary and surgery at 6 Prank-street, Alexandria. The society consists of the following members :—Idris Bey Ragheb, Soliman Bey Izzet, Ahmed Moustapha, Nessim Piha, Salomon Soury, Alfred R. Carasso, Elie Gabriel, Moussa Ibrahim, Doctor C. Saffi and Heddaya Bey.

div.head: Heliopolis Oasis.
div.p: The Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Co. has applied to the Ministry of Public Work for the right of procuring the stone supplies for their works in the Oasis from the quarries at Abbassieh. The Ministry, however, has replied to the Company declaring that such concession will be subject to tender, in which the Company can take part.

div.head: Black Maria.
div.p: A correspondent writes :—Upwards of fifty fellaheen arrested for neglect of the cotton worm regulations were brought here yesterday. They were taken to the police station in two vans, of the usual Black Maria type. In this warm climate it seems cruel to convey the prisoners in this way ; surely a open car with railings would be more congenial.

div.head: Ths Khediviah-Mother.
div.p: In view of the Khedivah Mother's intended pilgrimage to Mecca, the Ottoman Government has instructed the sanitary authorities of the Hedjaz to adopt such measures as will prevent any epidemic. "Al Mokattam," however, is informed that H.H. the Khedivah Mother has no intention of visiting the Holy Places this year, and the Daira of Her Highness has not received as yet any orders for the pilgrimage.

div.head: Boulac Bridge.
div.p: The chief engineer of roads and bridgee in France to whom the Ministry of Public Works had submitted the plans of the proposed swing bridge at Boulac, did not approve of them, and was in favour of a high level which would avoid the necessity for a swing bridge. The Ministry on its part, however, did not share the French engineer's opinion, and are now studying plans drawn up by Sir Benjamin Baker, for a bridge that will cost one-fourth less than the original estimates.

div.head: "Al-Djareedeh."
div.p: Ahmed Bey Lufty, who has been appointed manager of the forthcoming "national" paper, A1 Djareedeh," left recently for Europe with a view to study the European newspaper arrangements and to purcase a printing press and other necessary materials for "Al-Djareedeh. The President of the Legislative Council, Osman Pasha Ghalib. Hassan Bey Madkour and many other notables who first promised to take up shares in the "Djareedeh," have now decided to withdraw from the scheme.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: ENGLAND AND EGYPT.
THE MINISTERIAL PRESS.
IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT.
div.p: London, Sept. 1st.

An article on the Egyptian Question appeared in the "Daily Chronicle" yesterday, which is considered of great importance, as, in view of the high position that newspaper holds in the Ministerial Press of the Capital, the pronouncement is held to embody the views of the great majority of supporters of the present Government.

The "Chronicle" states that the policy of "Egypt for the Egyptians" is impracticable, as no man in his senses can believe that either the internal or external conditions, which such a policy would require, exist in present-day Egypt country is not as yet capable of self-government and has neither the experience, training, nor habits, which would enable her to stand alone. Even if Egypt were so able, the interests and jealousies of other States would effectually prevent her so doing. In fact the cry of "Egypt for the Egyptians" means nothing more nor less than the retrocession of that country to Turkey. Such an eventuality is obviously quite unattractive to the English supporters of a Liberal Government and the sooner this fact is clearly realised by the Egyptians themselves, the better it will be for all parties concerned. No better system of government in the best interests of the Egyptians could be devised than that which has been worked out by the aid of many years' experience by Lord Cromer.
THE ACCESSION FETES.
Egyptian Turcophiles have valued their loyalty to the Padishah at L.E. 326, the total amount realised by subscriptions for tonight's fêtes at Cairo.
There will be an evening party in the Urge Mussulman preparatory school at Saida Zenab Cairo, beginning at 7.30.
The band of the 2nd Bn. Royal Inniskilling Fus., will play in the Esbekieh Gardens from 9 to 11 p.m, to-night, on the occasion of the Fête.
THE "MAHROUSSA."
The Khedivial yacht Mahroussa is expected to leave the Clyde about the 15th September for Constantinople in order to be in waiting for the return of the Khedive to Egypt.
The balance of the credit at the end of last year for repairs to the yacht amounted to L.E. 33,450. Of this amount L.E. 26,229 has been spent, leaving a balance of L.E 7,221.
THE LATE PRINCE IBRAHIM.
PARIS, August 31.
The remains of Prince Mohamed Ibrahim have left for Egypt. The Princess his widow and Prince Hilmy accompany the coffin. (H.)
"VOLCANO" AT CAIRO.

The "Progrés," which was one of the Cairo newspapers that announced the rumour of a Volcano appearing on the Mokattam Hills, now gravely states that it has received the following telegram from Mr. Keeling, the Superintendent of the Helouan observatory :—

"Le bruit qu'un volcan se serait manifesté dans les environs de cet observatoire est absolument sans fondemeut. Ayez la bonté d'annoncer dans votre proohain numéro que je ne suis pour rien dans ce bruit."
PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
The following is a translation of a paragraph which appeared in yesterday's issue of "La Réforme" :—

A breeze of morality is being wafted over our city and there is no denying the fact. Of course we are on the side of virtue and we cannot but congratulate ourselves on the progress with which we are advancing on that path, which is filled with both roses and thorns. We, however, fail to grap why the most elementary rules of justice are overlooked and, on the pretence of pursuing and looking out for young ladies whose morals are dubious, it is forgotten that the liberty of the individual is sacred and that if that liberty must be violated, some other excuse is necessary than the good pleasure of a detective or the superabundant zeal of a police officer. We will not go into farther details far we hope that before the Commandant of Police goes on leave he will make some remarks to his subordinates on this head, as on others, and that we shall have no occasion to return to the matter.

A correspondent writes : — Surely the Alexandria Police are going too far in their puritanical zeal. Among their latest innovations is to insist that carriages with native women inside should have the hoods down even in the day time. Such a ridiculous enactment is even unknown in Constantinople.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN POST.
REPORT FOR 1905.
div.p: Saba Pasha's report on the work of the Egyptian Postal Administration during the past year is as usual a record of continuous progress. The number of letters carried in 1905 was 50,770,000 as against 45,330,000 in 1904, an increase of 12 per cent.
The foreign mails ware shared by the undermentioned countries in the following proportions : —

There are 76 Arabic newspapers and reviews published, 61 in European languages and 9 in other Oriental tongues. Of these 146 journals 86 are issued at Cairo, 50 at Alexandria, 4 at Port Said, 2 at Tantah, 2 at Assiout and 2 at Suez.
The number of parcels passing through the Post Office has increased from 672,800 in 1904 to 761,000 in 1905.

The Post Office Savings Bank Department increased enormously last year and the number of depositors rose 50 per cent. The total included 31,411 natives and 12,013 foreigners, as against 20,273 natives and 8,879 foreigners in the previous year.
The foreigners were divided as follows:
Italians, 4.313, Greeks, 2.918, Britishers, 1,898, French, 1,006, Austro Hungarians, 805, Germans, 343, Divers, 728.
The receipts increased to L.E. 215,917 in 1905 as against L.E. 191,037 in 1904, while the expenditure amounted to L.E. 149,656 as compared with L.E. 127,049.
Every feature of the report shows continuous progress and great credit must be given to Saba Pasha, the excellent Postmaster General, on the efficiency of his administration.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MUMMIES.
THE CAUSE OF TUBERCULOSIS.
div.p: A theory which has received something more than humorous consideration has lately been advanced by Dr. Rafaelle Sorgnac, lecturer on bacteriology at the Sorbonne, to the effect that the present prevalence of tuberculosis is due to the exhumation of Egyptian mummies. A few days ago we gave an abstract of this monograph.

In this monograph, which represents years of research, investigation and experiments in Egypt and France, Dr. Sorgnac traces the "Great White Terror," consumption, back to Egypt and down into the very tombs in which the ancient Egyptians of the Pharaohs were laid away thousands upon thousands of years ago.

Thus the startling monograph practically claims that if Napoleon had not invaded Egypt and looted the tombs of the ancient illustrious dead, carrying back in triumph to France tin mummified remains of Egyptian kings and queens consumption or tuberculosis would be practically unknown to day. Napoleon first looted the tomb; one hundred years ago, and Dr. Sorgnac points out that it was not until Napoleon's mummies and mummy oases reached France that tuberculosis got a foothold there. Just why that is so has at last been discovered by the French scientist. He has found that the mummies are teeming with living consumption germs. Bacteriologists have begun many experiments during the last ten years or so to ascertain just how long a consumption germs can exist in a bottled-up or perfectly dried-out condition. Germs bottled tea years ago are still alive. Dr. Sorgnac goes far beyond this in his declaration that the germs live for thousands of years, as he has proved through the germs found in the mummies. It is significant to add that epidemic of consumption broke out among the first body of workmen and scholars sent into Egypt to open the ancient tombs and prepare the bodies for shipment.
EGYPTIAN IVORY.
Egyptian ivory to the amount of over 16 tons has arrived in London to date for the quarterly sales on October 23rd. The total amount of ivory from all sources which has as yet arrived, is 23 tons.
THE SUDAN.

A most interesting artcle to English readers in the recent number of "La Revue" is "Sou-dan d'Egypt," by M. Jehan d'lvray, who who, dwelling at some length on the Earl of Cromer's report, and on the work accomplished by him and Sir Reginald Wingate, expresses admiration for the results of the occupation of the Egyptian Sudan by Great Britain. He concludes : "En somme, le Soudan d'aujourd'hui est bien la plus belle corquete de l'Angleterre."

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
OPENING OF MAAN-TEBUK SECTION.
div.p: Beyrout, Aug. 29.

The Messageries steamer "Orenoque" arrived here from Constantinople on Monday with the following distinguished personages on board: Sir Robert H. Drummond Hay, K. C. M. G., His British Majesty's Consul General at Beyrout, accompanied by Lady Hay, and His Excellency Field Marshal Rahim Pasha, Aide-de-camp of the Sultan, and Military Inspector in Macedonia.

Although the arrival of Lady Hay was rather unexpected, it having been Lady Hay's original intention to prolong her stay in the summer resorts of the Continent, yet the number of distinguished friends that went on board with their floral tributes was fairly large. Sir Robert, accompanied by Lady Hay, was received on landing with military honours.

His Excellency Rahim Pasha had an imposing reception with fall military honours. His Exellency Khalil Pasha, Vali of Beyrout, and the Commandant of the Beyrout garrison together with a great number of military and, civil officials, and spiritual dignitaries, hied to the reception of Rahim Pasha on the steamer's arrival in port.

His Excellency Rahim Pasha is accompanied by an aide-de-camp and a secretary, a colonel in the Ottoman Army. He has been delegated by the Sultan to attend the inauguration ceremony of the opening of the Maan-Tebuk section of the main line of the Hedjaz railway, which will take place on the 1st of September, the anniversary of the accession of His Imperial Majesty to the Throne. After taking refreshments with, and returning the courtesy to the Vali, Rahim Pasha proceeded at about 10 a.m. by a special "train de luxe" accompanied by Mr. Bourgain, director of the French railway and Rear-Admiral Faik Pasha, to Damascus, whence he will pursue his voyage on Wednesday to Tebuk, where the inauguration ceremony is to take place.

div.head: OCCUPATION OF SANA.
ORDER RESTORED.
div.p: ( FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT. )
Suez, August 31.
According to the latest reports from Arabia ; it appears that Ahmed Faizi Pasha has totally defeated the insurgents and reoccupied Sana.
Refugees arriving at Suez report that order has practically been restored in Arabia, and that mails are now regularly carried to and from Sana.
Owing to the excessive beat and hardships, the Turkish army lost a considerable number of men, who had as their only protection from the sun a fez
THE PLAGUE.
The bulletin issued to day shows no fresh case.
SAN STEFANO CASINO.

A Grand Symphonic Concert will be held to-morrow, including the new Fantasia of the Opera Samson and Delila. In the afternoon there will be vocal and instrumental concert, and variety entertainment at the New Theatre.

On the 20th September there will be a fete de nuit in honour of the Italian National Festival, This evening at the New Theatre a comedy in three acts, "Le Fiacre 117" will be given by M. A. de la Freydieres company for Mile Mary Fleurs benefit.
THE SHOUBRAH CRIME.

No proofs of his guilt have yet been discovered against the young man, who was arrested here and detained at the French Consulate in connection with the recent tragedy at Shuabra. The autopsy shows that Skopelitis was first stunned by a blow and afterwards strangled.
ATTARIN NATIVE COURT.

The Attarin Native Court has sentenced a native of Alexandria Mohamed Ahmed Awad, to two years' imprisonment with hard labour for criminally assaulting a Syrian woman, the daughter of a clergyman, on the 18th July last on the banks of the Mahmoudieh Canal. This morning the Court also sentenced a native of Tel el Baroud to three years' imprisonment for arson.

div.head: CONCERNING ANTHEMS.
UNSEEMLY CONDUCT AT CAIRO.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes under date of 30th inst.:—Yesterday evening the string band of the Inniskilling Dragoons gave an excellent concert on the terrace of the Continental Hotel, Cairo, which was much appreciated by a large audience consisting of English and Egyptians for the most part.

Though it is not the custom of the country to honour the anthem of his Highness the Khedive by rising whenever it is played, and though Egyptians are not in the habit or honouring it in this way, Englishmen in this country, and especially those in the service of his Highness, are in the habit of thus honouring his anthem, for the sole reason that it is always played by our military bands immediately before the National Anthem which it is every Englishmen's delight and duty to honour by rising and removing his hat, it being obviously an invidious and tactless act to make any distinction by sitting for the Khedive's hymn and thereafter at once rising to show respect to His Majesty King Edward.

In accordance with this custom, when the band rose on Wednesday night to play the Khedive's hymn, every Englishman rose to his feet, not because he felt he was observing the custom of the country by so honouring his Highness, but because he did not wish to seem to show more respect to his Sovereign than to the Head of the State in which he was living.
When, at the close of the Khedive's hymn the strains of "God save the King" were heard the Egyptian "gentlemen" present immediately, resumed their seats and one calmly walked out

This sort of return for an act of courtesy by Egyptians who affect to represent the cream of their society, engenders in all Englishmen present a great reluctance to thus honour the Khedive's hymn again.

The letter which appeared in the "Gazette" to-day from a resident of twenty years' standing serves to prove how it is possible to spend twenty years in a country and yet to remain in complete ignorance of some of its customs.

If hitherto certain English Government offcials have not always treated the Khedivial anthem with the respect with which they are bound to treat their own anthem, the reasons are that they do not see why they should rise if the Egyptians are not in the habit of so doing themselves, and also, yery probably, because they have experienced some such unseemly conduct as occurred on the Terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel yesterday evening.

div.head: CORN FOR EGYPT.
AMERICAN IMPORTS.
div.p: The latest issue to hand of the "Baltimore News" contains the following intelligence :

Within a few days the British steamer Mokta, bearing about 150,000 bushels of corn, will leave this port for Alexandria. It is the first shipment of corn to Egypt from this port for 12 years, and is the first time in the history of the local port, or perhaps in the history of any Atlantic port, that a full cargo of white corn has been exported. The Mokta left the Canton elevators yesterday, and is now finishing up her load at the Baltimore and Ohio elevators at Locust Point. In order to get her full cargo of white corn, the Mokta will carry out of Baltimore. every bushel of that variety in the city except a car that arrived this morning and is at Canton. It is hardly probable that she will return there for so small a quantity.

The cargo of the Mokta is to be used as seed corn and will be planted in the domains of the Khedive. Those same fields that once bore the thousands of bushels of golden grain where- with the granaries of the Pharaohs were filled against the time of famine are again to blossom forth from the seed furnished from a new world through the port of Baltimore.

A full cargo shipment of corn in July is uncommon, and when Messrs. Hammon & Snyder announced the charter of the Mokta for this purpose it occasioned no little talk on charge. When it was known that the Mokta's cargo consisted entirely of seed white corn more talk was occasioned on the floor of change. It made interesting delving into figures to know that, according to the modern system of planting corn, it takes bat a peck to plant an acre, so that the 150,000 bushel cargo of the Mokta will be sufficient to plant 600,000 acres of the fertile valley of the Nile.

div.p: The widow of the late Khedive Ismail Pasha left Constantinople on Thursday, and is expected to arrive at Alexandria shortly.

The secretary of the late Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim has given frs. 1,000 to the Bernay Hospital and frs. 500 to the Thiberv lle Benevolent Society in memory of his Highnees.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN PRESS.
A NEW ZEALAND INVITATION.
div.p: To THE EDITOR or THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—We are holding a grand exposition at our coming Exhibition in the form of a collection of the world's Public Prints (newspapers). It is not for an idle curiosity study, it is for the purpose of bringing to view an educational point on behalf of the tranquillity and progress of civilisation commanded by the Press, and also as an object lesson for the enlightening of our young generation to whom much of the "World of Life" is but a dream— aye, to many but a thought Using it in conjunction with the International exhibits, we hope it is to prove a bright mark, a mark of interest to the world at large and help to impress on all that "desired longing" that in the great future education will cultivate the "common friendship of man."

So we ask of you, Sir, as a favour for this unique occasion, if you would insert in your valuable columns an invitation to the Editors of your great paper world, inviting them to forward one copy of their press: Daily, Weekly, Illustrated or Magazine, in fact everything in the form of desirable public print; "let'em all come," for "all" we cordially invite.

The name and address of each paper will be so arranged that persons missing the voice of the lecturing interpreter can take a note and satisfy their own curiosity. We suggest, should it meet with approval, a sketch or photo of the Editor to accompany his copy ; or should the Editor suggest any particular part of his copy for exposition, his request will receive strict attention.
We are asking this favour all over the world, and so far have received most reassuring response.

We hope you will take a broad view with your worldly-wise knowledge of the good meaning of this exhibit, and help on behalf of the paper world and the unenlightened to make this collection absorbingly interesting.
Authors and press representatives visiting our Geyser-land during the Exhibition will be cordially invited to inspect.
Yours very truly,
JOHN A. SPECHANG.
Secretary W.M.P.P.E.C.
Address: Secretary,
World's Modern Public Prints
Exhibit Committee, Christchurch,
New Zealand.

This is how "Golf Illustrated" approaches the fish story. A friend of mine, writes a correspondent to that paper, was driving across a river–a fine, low shot–which just skimmed the water at the other side. A salmon leaped and caught the ball, but such was its impetus that both ball and salmon were carried high and dry on to the opposite bank. "He didn't tell me the weight of the salmon, but I fancy it was a thumper. It was bad lie, too." Very probable.

As a result of the court-martial on the Sveaborg mutiny 10 soldiers and 3 civilians were sentenced to be shot and 559 soldiers to various terms of imprisonment. The death sentences were carried out in the afternoon. (Reuter)
On the suggestion of the Tsar, M. Stolypin and his family are to take up their residence in the Winter Palace. (Reuter)

div.head:
AUSTRIA AND NEW ZEALAND.
PREFERENTIAL CUSTOMS.

div.p: A preferential customs agreement between Australia and New Zealand has been simultaneously introduced by the respective Parliaments. Mr. Deakin, the Federal Premier, also proposed to raise certain duties on foreign goods going into Australia by 10 %, giving a preference by that amount to Great Britain. (Reuter)

Mr. Bryan, addressing a meeting here, said that he was sure that England and the United States would make an arbitration treaty. He advocated the gold standard and condemned trusts and high tariffs. The time is ripe, he said, for the overthrow of plutocracy which was sapping the strength of the nation. (R.)

Mr. Bryan had a remarkable reception on landing here. He was welcomed by 10,000 people from all parts of America. This marks the opening of his presidential campaign. His candidature has been endorsed by many democratic conventions. (Reuter)
Arrangements have just been completed for the building of a Mahomedau mosque here at a cost a cost of £100,000. (Reuter)
The "Neues Tageblatt" announces that King Edward has advised Prince Ferdinand to avoid complications which are liable to provoke serious events in the Balkans. (Havas)
Mr. G. D. Natchevitch, the Bulgarian Minister, has left for Sofia. (Reuter)

The body of Lady Bannerman is to be embalmed and brought to Scotland for interment. World-wide telegrams of sympathy for Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman are pouring in The King's letter covered three pages. (R.)
Racked with Rheumatism.

"For a period of 12 or 13 years," says Mr. Thomas Little, 5 Block, Caledonian Buildings, MOTHERWELL, Scotland, "I was constantly troubled with rheumatism ; so bad was it at times that I had to give up work. I attribute my illness to a chill; when I had anything like a cold it flew to my kidneys. The urinary secretions were cloudy and full or sediment. But my worst trouble was I was crippled by sciatica and rheumatism. The pain was terrible in my left hip and thigh ; the sinews of my leg seemed to be contracted, for I could not put my heel to the ground. I could not straighten my leg, and could only step on my toes. There was an awful, constant gnawing pain. My shoulders and arms, also were full of aches ; my knee, too, troubled me, being badly swollen for years. The pain in my back, especially over the right kidney, was just as if a knife had been stuck into me. "This will give you some idea of my suffering. Then I read of the cure by Doan's Backache Kidney Pills of a case similar to mine, and decided to give them a trial. It was a happy resolve. Before I had finished the first box my back was easier ; not only that, but the rheumatism was much easier in my leg. I continued with the pills, and was cured. I need scarcely say I esteem them a most wonderful medicine." Mr. Little gave our representative the above account in February, 1904, and in June, 1906, more than
TWO YEARS LATER,
Mr. Little said: "I was completely cured by Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, and what is best of all I have enjoyed good health ever since."
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T, per BOX.

div.head: THE MOSLEM WORLD.
BRITISH POLICY.
WORDS OF WARNING.
div.p: Kader Effendi El Dana, President of the Beyrout Municipality and Editor of the "Beirut," writes as follows to the "Times" :—

Sir,—Your paper, enjoying as it does the wiest circulation in the world, and a well- merited reputation for the trustworthiness and veracity of its information, as well as an unbiassed judgment and sagacity, affords the best channel for the promulgation of a few ideas having a direct bearing on the vital interests of the British Empire.

England has always won the distinction of possessing the most astute, most far-sighted, and, in a word, the greatest of European statesmen ; and the majority of these have as a rule made it a point of cultivating friendly relations with the Ottoman Government and the Sultan of Turkey, so that England's friendship came to bea common fact the universal knowledge of which attracted to her the love of all the Moslems of the world.

It is a notorious fact that the Moslem world counts several millions, of whom about 100 millions are under British rule. These millions of Moslem British subjects have so far borne a faithful allegiance, and indeed a true love, to the British Empire, because it has always stood as the friend of the Sultan of Turkey, whose Caliphate is acknowledged by all the Moslems of the world.

And these 100 millions of Moslems are scattered far and wide in India, Aden, Cyprus, Egypt, and the Sudan, a formidable and vast force to hold together. The two last-named countires are essentially Moslem, and have been so ever since the rise of Islam. Egypt is the richest country in the world, and is, moreover, the key to India and the Hedjez, and yet this rule has been acquiesced in by the Moslems simply because of the accepted conviction that England was a true friend of the Sultan of Turkey, the Caliph of Islam. And yet we see that since a few years British statesmanship has undergone a change, the great men of State in England having lost, apparently, their keen political sense and far sightedness, and their philosophic judgment as to the vicissitudes of time, as well as their sober realization of the primordial fact that worldly institutions and the things of man's making are unstable and will pass away as others like them have passed before.

The Moslems now all over the globe look to British policy with a suspicious and a disappointed eye; and in spite of England's rule over Aden and Cyprus and India, and its occupation of Egypt and the Sudan we see her taking the lead in every campaign against the Ottoman Empire, not realizing, apparently, that this hostility may be regarded as meant against the whole Moslem world. For the Moslems of Morocco and Algeria and the African Sahara, and the Moslems of India and China, and Russia as well, although they are outside Turkish rule yet they turn to the Ottoman Empire as to a common goal of which the Sultan Abdul Hamid is the light, and the Caliph of their faith, aye the object of their constant prayer.

It will be remembered that during the agitation over the Cretan question England was in the van of the European Powers to aid the Greeks in bringing about the dismemberment of the island from the body of the Ottoman Empire and its ultimate union with Greece. But of what avail has this been to England? And in the recent movement on the part of the European Powers for the establishment of international control over Macedonia England is again in the forefront, and perhaps the only instigator. We cannot but marvel at the fact of the British people, well known for their sense of fairness and dignity, abetting the action of their Government in inciting several Great Powers to aggressive action against one single Power subsisting in a high state of civilization.

Does it become British statesmen to indulge in hostile demonstrations against the Ottoman Empire when all its multiple Moslem subjects have always been united in their love of England? Does it behove the statesmen of Great Britain to break the heart Islam through such uncalled for animosity against the Ottoman Government, which is the living representative of Islam, while she counts over a million Moslems among her subjects ?

If England has any friendly or conciliatory feelings towards the Ottoman Government, the Cretan question would not have assumed the turn it did. The Moslems would have preferred the cession of the island to England rather than to Greece.

If England had been moved with friendly and pacific intentions towards the Ottoman Government, none of the European Powers would have interfered in the Macedonian question. If she had any friendly intentions towards us or been actuated with sincere motives for the introduction of reform in Macedonia and other parts of the Empire, she might have sought the way of friendly counsel instead of inimical demonstration.

If British statesmen's desire and concern be the improvement of the condition of Christians in the Ottoman Empire, we have the testimony of their clergy and all their spiritual heads to prove that they are enjoying a great measure of security and better protection than in some other Christian countries.

But if the British Government mean by all these hostile demonstrations to compel the Sultan to acknowledge the independence of their rule over Egypt, this is a matter that may not be wholly in the Sultan's hands; and even if he should wish to concede this right, Islam would set itself against it.

The hearts of the Moslems have turned away from England because of the policy pursued for some time back by its statesmen and their unconcealed aggressiveness ; but there is an end to aggression, for "thy God is always on the watch." Let England not look to her greatness and her wealth and the strength of her Fleets, for the power of Allah is above every power.

Let the British people remember what they have suffered lately in a war with a small nation, what vast sums of money have been expended, what precious blood shed. The loss was tremendous, but, thanks to England's wealth and greatness, the humiliating reality was not quite betrayed to the world.
Let the British people look to Russia for a lesson and see what the vicissitudes of time have brought her to, in her late war with Japan, and in her present internecine struggle.

And just so might the British nation fall a victim to the same surprises of destiny, for "Allah waits but neglects not." And if circumstances should be adverse, unexpected breaches might be opened in the castle of her her national and colonial strength which she would be powerless to stop, and then all her treasures would be of no avail, and may fall like a drop in the ocean. It is, therefore, to be hoped that the wiser among British statesmen will revert to their old policy of friendliness with the Ottoman Government, and work hand in hand with the Caliph of Islam, the Sultan of Beni Osman; otherwise there would apply to them the Prophet's saying, "and if Allah wills a thing he deprives the wise of their wisdom." Then farewell to Gibraltar and Malta and Aden, farewell to Cyprus, Egypt, and the Sudan; aye, farewell even to India! Beware, therefore, of the might of Allah, for "great is the might of thy God!"
My object in this is a friendly counsel and not threat, for I am not of this cast of mind, but I have simply wanted to sound a note of warning about the vicissitudes of time.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
EXTRACTS FROM THE HOME PAPERS.
JAPAN AND THE POWERS.
div.p: Japan has informed the Governments of foreign oonntries that she has decided to open the port of Dalny to the commerce of all nations from September l and that it will be a free port so far as trade in the territory which she holds on lease from China is concerned. Trade, it is added, will also be permitted from the same date be!ween Dalny and cortain open ports in Japan. The principle of the "open door" will aooordingiy receive immediate appli- cation in the Liaotung Peninsula, but we Deed hardly say that this step does not of itself go very far towards a solution of the exceedingly intricate problem of the opening of Manchuria. It is a welcome earnest of the good frith of our allies, and of their readiness to aot up to the professions with which they went to war, but it may perhaps be doubted whether the change is likely to be of great praotic advan- tage to other countries at present. ("Times.")

At this moment, in various parts or the world the British Fleets are making peace and consolidating the Empire, which is their essen- tial idle. The work is being done in the best possible way, without the use of gun or torpedo, though' both weapons of force1 are silent faotors in the palavers of goodwill. The vis on every eagerly plans by artificial and dangerous methods to hasten the Parliament of Man, the Federation of the World ; he would try a short out to all men's desire by merely weakening British sea-power. Such thiokers deliberate hide from themselves the solid fotthat the British Fleet is a purely defensive foroe, on whose sifhoiency and efficiency the peaee of the nations centres, as does au arch on its keystone. They forget that even today it is the presence of British ships which keeps down piracy in the Malay A-chipelago, in. China waters, in the Red Sea, off the 11 of coast, and elsewhere ; that these same thips, whioh have gu irded the liberties of the Cretans, and put an invisible, but none the loss real, pressure on .tbe; master ci the Christians of the Near East, are the barriers agaiust the groath of slavery in regions where it would still be practised, but for the strength and ubiquity of England's right arm ; and, lastly, that these same symbols of might, and not less of meroy and protection to the weak, are continually aoting as ambassadors with kindly greeting to rivals and triends. ("Daily Telegraph.")

Eight years ago Lord Salisbury was makirg desperate, and unsuccessful, efforts to secure from Russia the opening both of Port Arthur and of Talienwan. Count Mouravieff had given the British Ambassador to understand that the Czar intended to open both places; but these, it turned out, were "ideas expressed very confidentially," and were Dot "assurances." The Russian assurances, and ideas that wereDot assurances, and occupations and leases: they have all passed into the lumber room ot musty archives and back numbers. Japan now roles in Russia's place. Her moderation in the hour of victory is the sufficient pledge for the reality of her intentions. She had set herself to win from the war no more than she had striven to obtain by peaoeful meats. She seoured by the Peace of Ports mouth more than that; and. had no idea whatever of continuing hostilities for further ends. In the same spirit Japan may oonfi dently be expected to oarry out fully and to the letter her promises of the open door in the leased territory and (so far as it rests with her) in Manchuria. ("Daily Chronicle").

The list of those goiog out to the various stations of the Church Missionary Society this autumn is, I am informed, very small wheu placed side by side with that of the vacancies ito be supplied. The Society are regarding with some concern the symptoms ot unrest among the Mohamedan population of Egypt and North Africa. It is felt that at the bottom of it lies the old contention between Mohamedanism and Christianity. Constantinople is not recognised as the centre of Islam. The centre ii practically in Cairo, where there is a theological seminary which has lasted for about a thousand years, and can boast ot having 10,000 students, they come from many parts of the world in order to master Arabic, which is their religions lan- guage, and then spread throughout all the countries where Islam is supreme. The Society are paying special attention to the vast popu lation inhabiting North Africa and the Eistern and Wistern Soudan, and from the latest reports their efforts promise to bo very successful. ("Yorkshire Post.")
It was Bismarck policy not to oppose England in Egypt, and we do not know of any weighty reasons to-day which could induce us to covet new Morocco laurels in Egypt –"Zeitung," Frankfort.

Germany's game is perfectly dear. After having long swayed between conciliation and the strong method, William II. has chosen peace. Thenceforth a rapprochement with Great Britain became the most pressing tank, and, to effect it, German diplomacy hwDOt spared ooqnetry.—("Joarnal," Paris.)

By some fortunate compenaation, the appalling havoc wrought by these earthquakes does not seem to produce a corresponding despair in the minds of the inhabitants. That was the most remarkable thing at San Francisco, where the pluck, cheerfmness, and unselfishness of the homeless people astonished every one who was brought into contaot with them. Those who came to inspect the ruined city let it with the feeling that the ruin had been almost worth while, in view of the generous qualities it called out among the Californians. In the same way, at Valparaiso, though peace and order are probably less per feet than they were in the American city, it is not of depression but of cheerfulness, and even high spirits, that we hear. Perhaps living on the Pacific shore iuduoes a light-hearted view of things. ("Times").

It is possible that President Roosevelt feel called upon to take action, but, if United States troops are to ocoupy the island until the "orderly government" contemplated in the Platt amendment to the Cuban Constitution is established, Washington may as well make up its mind to declare the nearest American equivalent to a Protectorate. The recent history of Cuba—which wds quite as happy and prosperous during its ten years of rebellion against Spain as at aoy other period—is a vivid illustration of the foolishness of foroing democratic institutions upon a people who possess none of the civic qualitiesas they are understood in a modern State. It is a moral which may be commended to the attention of the present rulers of the British Empire. ( 'Standard.")

The advisers of tha Dowager Empress of China seem to believe that ten to fifteen years will be ample to educate the people for a constitution on Western lines. The Shah of Persia seems to think such preparation unnecessary, but at the pains time he does not appear to have adopted any European system wholesale. The example of Japan has perhaps obioured the difficulties in the way of constitational reforms. What one Oriental country has done another may do, say the optimists, and while Persians are credited with great intelligence and richness the Chinese are usually allowed to have some of the best brains in the world. But the Japanese did not gain their victory by mentality, but by self sacrifice and adaptability. So far no other Oriental country has bagon, as Japan began, with the abdication by the privileged classes of their rights and by a wholesale commencement at the bottom rung of the ladder of learning. ("Morning Post.")
PLEASANT FOR SWIMMERS.

Here are pleasant statistics for swimmers in the Seine. During 1905 were fished out of the river between the boundaries of Paris : 101 human corf ses; dead dogs, 9,114 ; dead oata, 898 ; drowned rats, 2,869 ; oaroases of fowls, 168; docks, 36; rabbits, 215; sheep, 12; horses, 31 ; sucking pigs, 44 ; pigs-, 8 ; magpies, 26 ; turkeys, 29 ; oalves, 3 ; goats 9 ; porcupines, 4 ; miscellaneous dead creatures, 681, including one monkey and one snake. Apparently fish are the only creatures that are never found dead or alive in the Seine within Paris, The city must keep a small host of clerks oocopied in counting the drowned rats, guinea-pigs, porcupines, and other dead things which the river gives up.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit— within certain necessary limits— free discussion.
SORROWS OF EMPIRE.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
SORROWS OF EMPIRE.
To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir.—Upon this day of September 1, thirty years ago, the Golden Horn was orowded with vessels innumerable, from gorgeous State caiques filled with Ladies of the Imperial Falace to the common wherries of Lirnonn Iskelessq while on land all Stamboul had oolleoted as near they oould to the Moiqne of Ayob. The Turkish crowd is invariably well behaved, but this was an occasion on which unwonted excitement was permissible, for the lusty cheers which had just rent the air were a proclamation of anew reign and a new polioy, whose exponent now stood, girded with the Sword of Othman, at the door of the historic shrine. Closer watchers of that brilliant speotaole, and they inoladed the members of the Diplomatic Corps, were differently impressed by it, and more particularly by the central object of all this popular manifestation. It was a countenance, clear count in natural lineameuts, and bold and majestic in pose, which left on their minds an indelible mark : a portrait which they all took home with them that afternoon to Therapia : the face of Abdul Hamid. That free was a faithful representative of the obaraoter of the man who alone and unaided was to reverse the polioy of an Empire and introduce into a body politio verging on constitutionalism the centralization of anoieut Rome. But the task which lay before him was immense ; a weaker man would have suooumb- ed to it, or at least have gone to the other extreme of involving his country in a struggle which could only have resulted in its rain. Extinguishing the last embers of the illusrated Liberalism of Midhat, and by so doing extirpating from an antooratio system elements which are dangerous to its very existence, Abdul Hamid prepared to vindioate in the eyes of Earope his Sazirain rights over the sabject Principality of Bulgaria. In the war in which he engaged with Rassia he was worsted by the mutual jealoosly of his generals, and he had to appeal as a last resource to that sea Power which had save! Turkoy on a previous occasion. No sooner had this disastrous struggle ceased, that another loomed up on the distant horizon,and it was one which potentates dread far more than shot and shall and the loss of territory ; the fight against bankrupt-)) the inevitable seqiel of an exhausting cam- paign. The L:qridation of 1876 had been the heaviest blow that ever struck the devoted Enpire, for it transferred to other marts the prosperous trade of former days. Nothing daunted, however, the Saltan continued hit great task, and creating an intelligence service which has never been equalled, set to work to find out the onuses of his country's distress Official corruption- dogged his footsteps; al every turn be was deceived by traitors in every rank of life who woold have sold his Palace could they have got the price, and whose evil example permeated all society. To defeat theii malpraotices, he had reooarae to a plan which admirably suited the ease, that of setting a thief to catch a thief, or appointing seoret agents to spy out the real enemies of Turkey. It was not an investigation that could be completed in a day ; for the oanker was too deep seated to be instantly eradicated.

A decade was to elapse before the real faces were discovered. They were neither Yonng Turks, nor Old Tarks, or even Turks at all; but occupying the highest posts ofhonoarin the land, and robbing right and left, the real enemies of the Turkish Empire sought to min what they has already wrecked by preparing a coup d'etat for this very same anniversary, ten years ago. Humanitarian sentiment at West- minster was appalled by the scene of oarnage that Constantinople presented in the last days of August 1896 ; moralists have oondemned in this world and in the next the author of these tragedies, that oonvalsed Europe. But reasons political and not religions deoreed that terrible measure, just as they did the massacre at St. Petersburg last winter. None can uphold the bntohery of ten thousand subjects, bat iu tho case of the Aimenian horrors, alore snoh means were able to save a situation that threatened consequences even more terrible, for an Armenian revolt at the Ottoman oapital of the kind planned by the Armenian Com- mittee and their coadjutors woold have, had it not been anticipated by twenty-fonr hours, meant an irretrievable disaster to the whole Empire.
The indifference of official Earope at this oritical stage in the history of Turkey was proof enough of the absolate necessity of such so-called barbarity.

The military promenade it to Thessaly of 1897 restored in the opinion of Earope its admiration of the Tnrkish soldier,and although no more that one year bad intervened,we heard nothing farther about Armenian atrocities, which had died a natural death.

The international intervention in Maoedonia, a vain attempt to paoify Greek and Bulgar, is still fresh in the memory of all, and the Tabah Fiasco is but an affair of yesterday. We cannot see however what good either Great Britain or Turkey derives from squabbles provoked by interested parties. Rather we should recommend in view of the several interests, and points of oontact which they share in common, that a working agreement be come to that will solve once and for all the eternal Eastern Question. Surely British warships and Turkish bayonets are the best guarantees for peace in Europe.
XENOS.
Alexandria, September 1.
Change of Address

The Public are generally requested to take note that "The English Nursing Home," Cairo, has removed from its quarters at Bab-El-Louk to the House formerly occupied by Ibrahim Bey Cherif, Kasr-El-Nil Street, Cairo.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: st 24. Lieutenant G. A. Akers-Douglas, Argyll and Sutherland Highlandert, who recently took service with the Egyptian Government, and is now Inspector in the s1avery Department, was with that gallant regiment in Methuen's advance to the relief of Kimberley, and was present at the action of Modder River, the death trap of Magersfontein, and the fighting which resulted in Crorje's surrender at Paardsberg, where ha was severely wonnded (Queen's medal with two clasps).

It may interest all ranks of the 2nd Inniskillings at Cairo to know that the 1st Battalion will retain to Belfast on the 7th September m j from Ballykinlar Camp on the completion of the summer drills. The order of the regimental march throngh Co. Down has been oanoelled, and the battalion will return direct to Belfast.

On the 6th November next, Brevet Colonel H. F. M. Wilson, Rifle Brigade, will vacate the command of the 2nd Battalion at Chanbattia, on completion of four years at its head. Colonel Wilson took over the command of the battalion whilst it was quartered in Egypt, and his association with the. Brigade extends back to January 1878. He served with it in the Afghan War, 1878-79, inolading the capture of Fort Ali Mnsjid, the expedition to the Knnar Valley (medal with clasp), the Mahsood Waziri Expedition, 1881; and the late Sooth Afrioan War inolading the fighting for the relief of Ladysmith, the actions of Colenso, Vaal Kranfz, Tngela Heights, Pieter's Hill; the actions at Laing's Nek, and various operations in Natal and Orange River Colony and Cape Colony (mentioned twice in despatches, brevet lieutenant colonelcy, Queen's medal with silk clasps).

The 1st Battalion CouDangbt Rangers will leave Mullingar shoot the 4th March next, sod will embark on the 6 h at Southampton, en voyage for Malta per the SS. Braemar Castle. The battalion is due to arrive at Valetta on the 15th following, The gallant old 88th was last in Malta from 1840 to 1847, but the 2nd Battalion has been theie in the interim. It will go on what may be anything op to a twenty year tour of foreign service. The. 2nd Battalion lately in Egypt will remain on foreign service till farther orderr, no instruc- tions for its return home having been issued.

The first class battleship Dreadnought will be commissioned, at Portsmonth on the 1st September for series ot experiments of an in- teresting character. The huge battle-hip will be commissioned by Captain Baoon. It is a bit of the irony of fate that Captain Adair, late of the onfortonate Montagu, was to have hoisted the maiden pennant of the Dread- nought.

The commission of the scoond class oroiaer Minerva, Captain A. W. Way moo tb, having expired on the Mediterranean Station, she is to be re-oimmissioned for a farther term of service in those waters. She is due at Devon- port early next month, where she will get her new crew from the cruiser Talbot.

div.head: LAUNCH OF AN "ANCHOR" LINER.
div.p: Messrs. Barclay, Carle and Co. (Ltd.) launched from their shipbuilding yard at Whiteinch, a few days ago, a large steel screw steamer for the Indian service of the Anchor Line, of the following dimensions : — Length, 440 feet ; breadth, 53 feet ; depth, 326 feet moulded, with a gross tonnage of 6,200 tons, and a dead- weight capacity of 8,600 tons. The vessel, which has been built to the highest class of the British Corporation, will be fitted with triple- expansion engines, the cylinders being 29 1/2, 49, and 81 inches diameter, with 4fs. 6in., stroke, and will have three large double-ended boilers working to a pressure of 180 lbs.

The 'tween decks are unusually lofty, being 10 feet in height. The bridge deck extends to 156 feet, under which the engineers are berthed, and the remaining space is available for cargo or coal. The captain and officers will be berthed abaft of the navigating bridge on the boat deck. Superior accommodation has been provided on the bridge and promenade decks for 90 first-class passengers in two and four- berth staterooms, which are exceptionaly large and airy. These are painted enamel white, and are famished with everything conducive to the comfort of passengers, including electric fans.

At the fore-end of bridge deck the saloon is placed, which is a spacious apartment. The woodwork is entirely of polished oak of light shade, with white Lincrusta on the ceiling. The furniture is also of oak. From the saloon a handsome double stairway leads to the musicroom on the fore part of the promenade deck. This room is panelled in satinwood, with inlaid tulip band, the panels being decorated with artistic mouldings, and the ceiling covered with French Lincrusta of suitable pattern.

This room will also be used as the ship's library, and be furnished with the necessary bookcase, also piano and writing tables. On the after part of the promenade deck is the smoking room. This apartment is panelled in walnut. The upholstery work is in blue and gold moquette, and the ceiling is covered with French Lincrusta. From this room there is a special stair leading down to the accommodation on bridge deck.

The vessel is fitted throughout with electric light, including a searchlight for navigating the Suez Canal by night. An insulated chamber for storing meat, vegetables, and fruit has has been provided, the refrigerating machine being placed in the engine room.

The Castalia, as she is named, will be despatched from Glasgow and Liverpool on her first voyage to Bombay in November, and will be commanded by Captain Blight, late of the Assyria. She is expected to make the passage in 22 days.

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication 1a construction de 2 égouts à fond perdu à Ibraoimieh et Bulkeley (Ramleh).
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 40.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. è midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Admiaistrateur de la Municipalité, avant le 4 Septembre 1906.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation, le même jour à 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter eu outre la mention "Soumission pour Construction de 2 égouts à Ibrahimieh et Bulkeley (Ramleh).

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale, avant l'ouverture des offres et an pius tard le 4 Septembre prochain à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Le Vice-Président,
(Signé) DR. SCHIESS.
Alexandrie, le 27 Août 1906. 28411-3-2
